author: Birdhouse

description.text: A cube cut in half along a skewed angle, for tuning purposes.

I was having problems fine tuning the extrusion temperature, print speed, and cooling parameters -- extrude too hot or too fast and there'd be blobbing on the top, extrude to cool and the inside perimeters wouldn't stick. This object did a good job of reproducing the problems for tuning.
Using Slic3r, I print with 3 perimeters, 0 layers, and 0 fill density.

"Wow, that is one strong drink!"  
A chalice for Ted, the King of the Hipsters

print_settings.Notes:: There are cut outs in the side for the probes that come with the kit. The bigger hole on the right side allow use of the ZIF socket lever and surface mount transistor testing pads.

description.text:
This design is a case for an ESR meter (transistor/resistor/capacitor/diode/inductor) purchased from ebay. It can be bought as a kit or ready build (the latter is recommended for the price).

These ebay clones are based on the work by Karl-Heinz Kübbeler, this page contains full details including a manual that explains its operation:

https://www.mikrocontroller.net/articles/AVR_Transistortester

You can find my design in Onshape where you can copy it and edit it.

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/4c7d857a2b899b8391ab2a0b/w/a62ee55e23da096c7296b15e/e/1b39e92417e16c690e9eee98

The ebay title of the item I bought is:

2016 EZM328(GM328R)transistor tester/ ESR / frequency meter / square wave genera

A link is (which will probably expire, try searching for the above text):

http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/331800112138?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Printer:

Hictop Prusa i3 3DP-17

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Support is needed for the top not the bottom. The PLA I used was not great and it only works at 0.2, head 210 degrees, bed 50 degrees. It took about 3 hours per part to print at approx 32m of filament each.

The case screws are M4 12mm, you could probably use similar self tapping screws or modify the design. I drilled through the bottom holes to widen them slightly and let the M4 create a thread as they are screwed in.

The two front 2 PCB screws (I did not bother with the rear) were PC case screws for hard drives at approx 3.4mm thread diameter and approx 5mm long, any self tapper or similar should do.

The switch should be available easily or can be left off, I just cut the battery wire and soldered it to the switch.

There are cut outs in the side for the probes that come with the kit. The bigger hole on the right side allow use of the ZIF socket lever and surface mount transistor testing pads.

Couple of ideas for marking your luggage for easy identification.

A name tag that simply says "This is not your bag". Hopefully keeps others away from your bag at the airport. This should be printed in two colors, and changing filament mid-print is enough for that.

A stencil for painting a simple figure on your luggage to differentiate it from hundreds of other similar bags. Scale to wanted size, protect outsides with newspaper or something and spray paint it on the bag.

description.text:
Chasecam for paragliding or paramotoring

8 fins needed, attached to the front.
Fins secured with tiewraps to each other and to the the front.
Gopro attachment sticked to the front and secured with a 4mm screew.

Hangingline attached in the balance point on the sides,not on the top.
I filed a small notch on the fins where the lines comes so the lines wont move.

Printed with ABS, if it breaks some cold winterday, I will print it with flexible filament.

Settings:
Layer height 0,2mm
sides, top and bottom thickness 1.2mm
no supports needed
Infill 50%
Printspeed 60mm/s
no cooling

comments.text: I just tried designing one for myself for the first time.  It looks great but the first time I threw it to the ground 2 of 8 hinges popped and cracked.   I printed in standard PLA.  My printer doesn't handle flexible filaments (Replicator +) so I will try changing the attachments to make them stronger.  They are too weak.  I like your concept.  It is simple, strong and removable.

title: V2 - Xiaomi Mi Band 2 replacement wrist band / chain

description.text:
Magnetic, filament-fused Mi Band 2 replacement wrist band

Unfortunatly my original MiBand wristband just broke. I always wanted a band that looked more like that of a metal watch. So this is my replacement design.

What you need

  • 3D-Printer
  • Raw bits of 1.75mm filament
  • 4 magnets (6mm diameter x 3mm)
  • Superglue

Post your I Made One if you did.

Have fun printing | running | fusing | timeing | monitoring

Assembly

Connect as many links as you need to the ends of the shell. Stick small bits of raw filaments into the holes. Then connect the two magnetic endparts.
I heated up a thick needle with a lighter and poked in each end of the raw filament. By doing this the ends of the filament bit expanded and it couldn't fall out anymore.

Last but not least glue two magnets in each endpart

The individual links are fused together with raw bits of 1.75mm filament

comments.text: What is the diference between this and the old version?
comments.author: Richysss

comments.text:
The individual links are not as long in the second version as in the first one. So the band has a better fit to your arm.
Furthermore the magnet lock has been redesigned to close more securely

Dispositif d’éclairage pour Dagoma DiscoEasy :
Il permet d’avoir une lumière d’ambiance puissante et froide sur votre imprimante préférée…
Vous aurez besoin de 2 lampes G4 led et des douilles qui vont avec. Les miennes proviennent de chez Conr.. (Revendeur de matériel électronique entre autre). Cela vous en coutera une dizaine d’euros. J’ai choisi les 30Watt (qui n’en consomme que 3 chacune de quoi assurer un très bon rendement)
Je commande les miennes depuis Octoprint via l’enclosure-plugin et les relais connectés à mon Pi mais vous pouvez installer un inter bien-entendu, le tout raccorder a une alim 12v.
J’ai imprimé les premiers modèle avec du Fiberlogy HD que j’ai recuit mais je pense que n’importe quel fil peut faire l’affaire car les lampes ne chauffent pas énormément.
Pardonnez-moi les vis non sexy, je les changerai pour mettre de tète plus petite ainsi que ma disco qui est en cours de modif EVO (j’attends désespérément mes vis trapézoïdale pour l’axe Z….)
J’espère que cela vous plaira.

My wife was at IKEA and bought wardrobe rod KOMPLEMENT (item number 22724). The problem was that she forgot to bring the fitting/seizures (do not know what the exact English word would be) for vertical installation under a cabinet.

What is the problem when one owns a Wi3? Of course none, you sit down and draw a fitting, happy wife!

Happy wife = many new shares available for withdrawal in an emergency.
Should you save the day for your wife (or husband) it's nice if I could contribute with my seizures.

Attached find you SolidWorks file and STL files. SolidWorks file contains two configurations, one for the double-fitting and for the simple (end fitting).

Have printed the parts in PLA I bought from E3PRINTABLE.NO, really good quality and nice sharp colours.

Will upload some photos as soon as I find the time to arrange them.

Update 01.04.2017:
Had to increase the diameter in the rod holes. The printer have possibly been a bit tight fit between the buildplate and the nozzle. Choose to increase the diameter just to make sure that there will be enough room for the rod.

A DIY polishing station to smoothen 3d-printed parts built using Arduino and portable humidifier.

Note: Only tested on Polymaker's Polysmooth filament and 70% ethyl alcohol.

Polymaker's Polysher in combination with Polysmooth is a revolutionary product. I wanted one.

However, since I missed the Kickstarter campaign, I didn't want to pay higher ticket price plus I can't wait for May for the pre-orders to get shipped so I decided to make one instead.

Having an Arduino kit lying around, I only needed to find a suitable humidifier/mister and container to build the polishing machine.

After, weeks of waiting forcomponents, finalizing the Arduino sketch, and printing the parts, here's the result!

As I have several parts left over from previous projects and been sourcing out most of the parts from China, my total cost for this build was a little over $50. Here's the link to the bill of materials.

See Change Log section for the component connections (Fritzing diagram) and the Arduino sketch.

DISCLAIMER
Should you decide to build one yourself, I cannot be held liable/responsible for whatever injury or damage that you incur as a result from the making and/or improper use of this machine.

Operating the DIY polishing station Initial setup Eevee model printed using PolySmooth (Snow White) with 1.6mm wall thickness, polished for 35 mins. using 70% ethyl alcohol. Printed cute octopus using Polysmooth Natural (from Polymaker sampler pack) Close-up of the polished cute octopus

2017-04-03:

  • Added piezo buzzer mount to power panel
  • Uploaded Fritzing diagram

2017-04-04

  • Uploaded Arduino sketch
  • Uploaded screw gasket STL file (printed using PolyFlex material)
  • Started drafting the User's Guide

2017-04-05

  • Added screw cover to gasket to protect screws from getting exposed to alcohol (printed using PolyFlex material)

2017-04-06

  • Uploaded exploded view and suggested optimal positioning of humidifier cover in relation to the polishing platform
Fritzing diagram showing how the electronic components are connected. Bottom right shows the portable humidifier PCB connected to a relay. Screws shown with gaskets and cover added to prevent liquid from seeping in the screw holes and protect screws from alcohol exposure Exploded view showing 3D-printed and some electronic components Optimal position of humidifier cover in relation to the polishing platform. This ensures that mist coming from humidifier will easily reach the platform. Also, being in the front (rather than the back) makes the mist more visible while polishing.

Bulbasaur model printed using PolySmooth (Snow White) with 1.6mm wall thickness, polished for 35mins using 70% ethyl alcohol. Before and after polishing: Charmander model printed using PolySmooth (Snow White) with 2.0mm wall thickness, polished for 45mins using 70% ethyl alcohol.

PARTS OF THE POLISHING STATION

IMPORTANT!

INTERACTING WITH THE POLISHING STATION

The polishing station is equipped with a control panel with a LCD and rotating push button to allow the user to interact with the machine.

The LCD will show different information and status depending on which mode the machine is on.

The rotating push button allows the user to send inputs to the machine and/or trigger various actions. There are three (3) ways to operate the rotating button:

  1. Click - quick push and release of the rotating button
  2. Hold - pushing the rotating button and waiting for two (2) seconds before releasing
  3. Rotate - this is accomplished by rotating the button either clockwise or counterclockwise


OPERATING MODES

The polishing station has three (3) modes:

  1. Ready/idle mode
  2. Setup mode
  3. Polishing mode

The machine starts in Idle mode upon turning on.

comments.text: Great build, I stumbled upon this only after I had ordered a humidifier from amazon and while it produces good water mist the ethanol that im feeding it gets "nebulized" but only very thin. I can feel and smell the mist but its invisible. I wonder if its the humidifiers fault. Any ideas?
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: Did you get the bottle caps humidifier I posted in the BOM list? Or you got a different one?
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: I have a different one, a bigger unit. and im using 70% atm. if I read that right down in the comments the bottlecap unit is very similar to the one they use in the original machine? So I better get my current unit returned.
comments.author: chiz

comments.text: Probably that's the reason. Before I settled with this final design, I tried several humidifiers and misters. From those ultrasonic misters that are used in fountains to car and aromatherapy oil diffusers. The bottle caps diffuser works the best and the easiest to tear down and get the components. It also seems the same type that is used in the Polysher because of the similarity of the components, i.e., look and size of the membrane and the wick. I suggest get the bottle caps humidifier, test it first with water and alcohol just to be sure it's not defective before you gut it out.
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: Got the BOM humidifier now and it works great. Interesting though maybe its the way the liquid enters the ultrasonic plate. In my old unit it sit on the bottom of a puddle and the mist has to work through the liquid. In the BOM unit the mist can escape directly.
comments.author: chiz

comments.text: I think it's more of the frequency of the vibrating membrane. I've proven this while trying out various ultrasonic humidifiers. Apparently, different liquid substances have different vibrating frequencies to break them down into mists/droplets.
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: Could you give pictures or details about how the pogo pins are set up. I can't tell from your pictures. Especially on the humidifier part I can tell from having the parts in my hands that the housing attaches to the bottle, and goes up into the cap but how do I set up the contacts inside the cap?
comments.author: jsondag

comments.text: Sorry didn't update this lately... Anyways, I removed the pogo pins and resorted to having a more permanently attached lighting as I noticed that over time the pogo pins have been corroded by the alcohol vapors which caused the pins to lose contact with the PCB causing intermittent lighting. Instead, I used a LED strip attached under the lid (together with the electronics) making it more protected from the vapors.

comments.text:
Thanks for your reply.
I think the Problem is with the wick in combination with the highly concentrated isopropanol (99.9). If i let the wick soak a few minutes on the top side (membrane) then there is shortly a acceptable amount of mist. After about a minute the top side of the wick is totally dry and the humidifier cover gets quite warm.
Maybe the highly concentrated isopropanol kills the suction of the wick.

It was this conversation that led to the manual cart I designed, along with the Magic Eraser wick.

title: FPV Camera mount fatbee FB90 / CM275T on e010 0.4g (customizable)

description.text:
inspired by the newly published customizable mount generator http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2023426 I have had an issue with the size of smaller cameras. If you want to use the lightest option on a e010, H36 or similar every thenth of a gram gives you a longer endurance and lift. Therefore only 2 (origin) screws needed.This mount can be printed with a weight of 0.4g.

So, i did a quick and dirty optimization for the 3.4g Fatbee FB90 AIO spare camera from Banggood http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-Fatbee-FB90-Micro-Racing-Quadcopter-Spare-Parts-5_8g-25MW-48CH-VTX-520TVL-CMOS-14-Camera-p-1108072.html

The e010 with original frame, two blade props chopped from origin, myLipo 235mAh 4.35V HV battery, camera mount and FB90 camera has a flight weight of 25.8g. Could be reduced wth a lighter frame and removed heat tube from antenna to app. 24g.

Update 2017-04-05: The CM275T camera http://www.banggood.com/CM275T-5_8G-25mW-48CH-NTSCPAL-Mini-VTX-600TVL-FPV-Camera-for-DIY-Micro-FPV-Racer-p-1102464.html seems to be identical to the FB90 cam except for the 600TVL on the CM275T (the sensor does on both cams 480NTSC/540PAL lines only).

STL has 15° or 10° camera angle. Other angles can be done by changing the SCAD file.

Due to the big capacitor on th right side of the origin board a small plastic part to be placed below the mount on the left side (see picture) to get the camera mounted levelled.

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 MK2/S/3 Filament Guide ClipOn

title: Prusa i3 Filament Guide Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
First, I replaced the shipped spool holder on my Prusa I3 with this one:
Spool Holder for Prusa i3 MK2 - Hex Design

To prevent pulling the filament sideways off the spool, I needed a filament guide. I made the Filament Guide ClipOn by Area51 first, but after some usage, I improved a few things:

The loop was originally with a parallel gap between both halves, meant to close when put into the holder. But that cannot work this way because it then closes only at one end, the loop side remains open. I changed the gap to a "v", so now it compresses correctly and closes the gap when put into the holder. Also i extended it a bit for a better fit for the spool holder.

Next, I redesigned the ClipOn a little bit higher and more to the front, now a collision with the X-Axis is less likely when operating at high Z values, the hole for the filament storage is also a little bit bigger.

If you use very narrow spools, I made a variant without the filament storage.

comments.author: MartinMajewski

comments.text: The fitment betwwen 2 items are too tight. I had to sand away a lot of material on the slot. I suggest reviewing the dimension and account for tolerance. Otherwise, good design.
comments.author: lzzhang10

comments.text: The dimensions are even too much on the loose side: the loop is 2 x 5.5 = 11 mm wide and 3.0 mm thick. The pocket in the clip is 11.4 x 3.2 mm. If the print is exactly calibrated, it shouldn't stick at all. But normally, the printers print a little bit too wide, so you get a litte clamping.
comments.author: lzzhang10

comments.text: Got ya. Thanks. Any recommendation on calibrating printing accuracy?
comments.author: stephanbrunker

comments.text: Not really, it depends on the printer firmware and the slicer settings. I can imagine two scenarios: If the axis is told to travel 100 mm, it should do exactly that, the correlation between motor steps and axis movement is part of the firmware. Also part of that equation is the backlash, it adds to the width of the part and may be compensated. If that is correct, you have the extrusion width on the slicer, means how fast the extruder motor works in relation to the needed width. But the latter is more tricky because it defines if a surface is completely filled or has gaps or too much filament.
comments.author: lzzhang10

comments.text: I will look into it the next time i have a chance to print something similar that needs fitment. As far as I know, my outer dimension is pretty accurate (+/- 0.05), as I did a calibration cube before. It maybe the inner dimensions. For your design, the slot's width also have to do with bridging, layer height, etc... Thanks!
comments.author: stephanbrunker

comments.text:

I wont be printing very high with 50g so im not worried about hitting the x carriage. See my make for what im having to do now.

description.text:
Easy pump with arduino and Stepper motor.
https://youtu.be/dSlVYtNwtlo
i use:

6x bearings: 10x5x4 mm
NEMA 17Stepper motor with 5mm shaft
steper driver pololu A4988
Arduino Nano
rezistor 10k
switch
silicone pipe 5x3mm
some screws M3,M2 and nuts

arduio code:
int x;
const int buttonPin = 2;
int buttonState = 0;

void setup()
{
pinMode(6, OUTPUT); // Enable
pinMode(5, OUTPUT); // Step
pinMode(4, OUTPUT); // Dir
digitalWrite(6, LOW); // Set Enable low
pinMode(buttonPin, INPUT);
Serial.begin(9600);

}

void loop()
{
buttonState = digitalRead(buttonPin);

Serial.println(buttonState);

if (buttonState == HIGH) {

digitalWrite(6, LOW); // Set Enable low
digitalWrite(4, HIGH); // Set Dir high

for (x = 0; x < 4000; x++) // Loop 200 times
{
  digitalWrite(5, HIGH); // Output high
  delayMicroseconds(300); // Wait 1/2 a ms
  digitalWrite(5, LOW); // Output low
  delayMicroseconds(300); // Wait 1/2 a ms
}
delay(1000); // pause one second

}
else {

digitalWrite(6, HIGH); // Set Enable low

}

}

title: Prusa i3 Mk2 Fan Nozzle Redesign

description.text:
On the left side of the fan of my new Prusa I3 Mk2 is a small protrusion where the fan nozzle rest against. Unfortunately, this little, little piece broke off and now there was no stability against pushing the nozzle upwards. Because the fan has a certain wall thickness, it was the logical way to make a rebate on the nozzle which fits that thickness and give a proper fit between nozzle and fan. I also changed the air divider a bit regarding that the flow is stronger on the outside and i imagine that the air destribution is more even now. Cannot test this, of course.

I also removed the nick on the left side, don't know for what this was for.

description.text: more n gauge railway models

2017/04/30 New stl. model added

Project and enclosure are still under development!

I wrote a Blog-Post about wiring and connecting to the Home-Automation-Server - Fhem. https://blog.moneybag.de/sds011-feinstaubsensor-fuer-fhem/

This is a simple enclosure for a SDS011 Nova Dust Sensor. I didnt find a useful enclosure on the internet, so i quickly designed one.

The dust-Sensor measures the dust and in combination with an WeMos it will send the results into the cloud or to your homeautomation-Server. JSON is supported.

The Sensor you can buy from eBay: http://ebay.to/2nq1ROk in China (not expensive)
Made with ESUN-PETG-Filament: amazon -> http://amzn.to/2oUqTWq

I used PETG because i am using this case outside, and PETG has a better temperature-stability.

More Information about Dust - Sensors you find here (in German): http://luftdaten.info/feinstaubsensor-bauen/

Seperate BME 280 Case here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2403728

title: Universal filament holder with ball bearings

description.text:
I design this low friction filament holder because i would not need to tighten a nut when i switch spool, which I had to do on my old filament holder. In the second image you see how to assemble the filament holder and a list of parts a bit further down in the text.

Some specifications:

  • quick Change
  • spools with a center hole of 34mm or bigger
  • supports spools up to a width of 120mm
  • can be monted on a wall
  • can be mounted under a shelf

Necessary parts:

  • three 608 bearings
  • 150 or 160mm 8M threaded rod
  • two 8M nuts
  • three 8M washers
  • 3 or 4 screws

author: GRay_111111

description.text:
Just thought I'd upload my Jedi food capsule, I made this for my hubby's Star Wars cosplay as I couldn't find any designs online. They measure 57mm by 6mm, exactly as in the movies. The join on the clip is not movie identical as I'm still learning how to create models but it won't be visible from the front anyway.

I have just edited it to have a more sturdy clip, as that was the weakest point in the design.

It'll need supports, but is easy to clean up with a scalpel.

In PLA at 0.1mm layers and 30% infill for strength it takes about a 50 minutes to print one on my printer (50mm/s), and 6 hours to print 8 :-) If printing in ABS I recommend printing just one at a time, as the model doesn't cool down as much and so the layers bond better.

Have fun! :-)

title: Gillette Mach 3 Razor Holder with Colour Ring

description.text:
This is a holder for a Gillette Mach3 Razor. It uses a sucker that attaches to bathroom tiles, mirrors or other polished surfaces which is then hidden by the body of the holder. The spacer ring is used to tension the sucker so that it has a tight hold on the surface, but also acts as a customisation option for households with more than one razor - print it their favourite colour!
Update I also included a slightly lrge spacer if your ring doesn't tension the sucker gainst the wall enough.

The sucker I used was left over from a bathroom toy but they are similar to the ones found here: https://goo.gl/SAlZPb Please note the 36mm would be the correct size but I haven't tested it from this source!

Print the ring at 100% infill and the other parts at whatever feels best. I think mine were printed at 20% infill.

Post your makes I would love to see them!

This is an compact Y idler design for Tevo Tarantula with integrated belt tensioner. It is a more compact design than the stock idler, making the printer a bit shorter in the Y axis. Belt tensioner slide has 20mm of available tensioning movement.
Uses stock belt pulleys:
2 - M5
1 - M3

X Version

UPDATE 1: Adding Lid.stl again, failed to upload first time
UPDATE 2: Apparently added wrong version of Lid.stl in last update. Pushing out the correct version (Lid.stl only)
UPDATE 3: Added version for stock 9mm wide pulleys
UPDATE 4: Added version with 2cm offset for extra bed clearance if needed.

description.text:
This is a wheel hub centric ring that fits into RONAL wheels with 68mm inner diameter and that centers on 54,1mm hubs used on Citroen, Daihatsu, Hyundai, Kia, Lexus, Mazda, Nissan, Opel, Peugeot, Subaru, Suzuki, Toyota and maybe others.

The design was derived from a single centric ring I purchased assuming I would get a set of four. It fits well into my RONAL wheels and to my little TOYOTA IQ. It might fit to other wheel makes and vehicles, as well.

I suggest to print only one in first step to test the fitment and then do the others later on.

Warning: Wheel hubs become hot during hard brakings. Use heat resistant material like ABS or PETG. PLA will most likely melt quickly.

remixed_from.author: andreasL
remixed_from.title: Axe Z pour smartrapCore (alternative Z axis)

description.text:
Based on RyandGarrison's revised brackets and the newer SmartRapCore files up on Onshape. The brackets should fit within the box (rather than sit on top), allow for printed plastic pulleys around the 608zz, have the removable Z-axis like the newer SmartRapCore + save quite some space on the X axis as compared to the original.

I'm in the process of finishing this build, some things might not be entirely correct yet but it's getting there. Will follow up with more details and build guide once my build is done. See the photo for my work-in-progress.

Also, I used this Ikea 'Eket' box that fits a printer with these parts perfectly. Much better than designing your own enclosure. http://www.ikea.com/nl/nl/catalog/products/20334597/.

Update 8th oct 2017:
I've finished this build some time ago, haven't been able to do a write-up yet but have updated all files and included a ton of pictures by which could should be able to deduce how it's built... Files with a "vX" (e.g. v7) in the filename are designed by me, all others are taken from the projects listed as source (credit where credit is due) but included here for completeness.

In terms of quality I'm quite impressed, I can get very decent quality prints at 130mm/s travel and 80mm/s print speeds at 0.2mm layers. Could probably push it quite a bit further for course prints if the hot-end could handle it.

Update 15th Jan 2018:
Added Fusion 360 source files. Feel free to edit to your liking, but share the results on Thingiverse! Also, happy to say that I can print up to 150mm/s (move 200mm/s) with fair accuracy.. although it will only achieve those speeds on some parts due to acceleration rates (1000mm/s).

Printer:

Prusa i3 clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

title: Krazee Klamp-O-Motor Parametric Small Motor Mount

description.text:
I needed to firmly clamp a motor that has a different diameter on one end than the other. So, I needed a bracket that would support the motor at the same shaft height with different diameters, and... Opa! The Krazee Klamp-O-Motor was born!

You set diameter of the motor (or other cylindrical thing) and presto! You can also set center height if you like, and thickness and bolt hole diameter. There is a simple nut trap so you can draw the clamp tight around the motor.

Designed to be easy to print. No support material required.

Docs? No docs. Read the SCAD. It's simple.

description.text:
Extreme deep-dish storage solution (13" x 13" x 4" deep) for game tiles or other collections, which fits neatly into my previously published Ikea Expedit or Kallax storage shelf/bookcase trays. Designed for easy carrying and to hold modest amounts of weight. The provided templates (two pages) have a blank space that you might fill with other cutting patterns and are designed with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. You can customize them at your own leisure with labels and text as demonstrated in the pictures provided. (I am not promoting one set of dungeon tiles tiles over the other, printing the ones I have). Depending on the divider configuration you choose, this baby will hold up to nine dozen 4" x 4" tiles or nine models or structures no larger than 4 inches on a side.

Formatted for cutting on two 3mm MDF cut from (Arch C) 24" x 18" sized sheets, which each fit across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

Here is an updated model for the Hypercube mount. This is used to mount a Nimble and an E3D V6 to the Hypercube, making it a compact little Direct Drive unit.
It uses the standard ducting to cool the print and has 2 brackets for sensors, the induction and the BL Touch.

Edit: It seems I used a non-standard shaped duct for the print cooling air. I have added the STL's for the duct. Apologies for the original creator of the duct, I cannot find it anymore, otherwise I would have linked to that thing page. If you know who it is, please let me know so I can add it here.

Edit2: Gave a little more space for the duct. Some users showed me that the duct had to be jammed in there. Now there is a little bit more space. Basic Mount Single V2.1.

The STL models are checked and optimised. The parts that need a different orientation to print properly are rotated to the preferred printing position.

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I further remixed the rear sensor holder... This time a customizable design and featuring also a screwable clamp for easy installation and removement! The general idea is from LucaCap's rear bed leveling sensor holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1883473). All credit for the fantastic design and idea goes to him! Nevertheless, the original design requires to tap threads into the metal bearing.

This modified design is equipped with plasic dowels, which fit in the (non-threaded) holes on the back of the linear slides and are secured with M3 screws (e.g. M3 x 10mm). NO THREAD TAPING REQUIRED!

The download section holds the basic vairants for a 18mm, a 12mm as well as for a 8mm sensor! For further options or versions use the CUSTOMIZER!

Variants:

  • Clip - as the version before with further improvements and customizable parameters
  • Screw - use a screwable clamp to secure your sensor to the back of your linear slide! This enables easy installation and removement and does not allow the sensor to move at all.

Note: depending on your sensor and your cable management you may loose some centimeters of available print height due to a interference of sensor and printer frame.



Firmware configuration:
Due to the altered sensor position the following changes have to be done in the configuration.h file (search vor the capitalized string and adapt the subsequent numbers):
With my E3Dv6 mount / carriage:
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 51

With the stock carriage:
#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 26
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 51

Additionally for all setups:
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 51

NOTE: If you added a custom offset, adapt the Y-parameters above correspondingly!



(Note for those who don't own a sensor yet: I use this sensor)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Recommended Screws:

  • Mount/Dowels: M3x10
  • Clamp: M3x10

title: E3D mount for K8200
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an adapter to mount the E3D v5 hotend on the K8200 extruder.
For the E3D v6 version of this mount, see here.

It uses the same long M3 nuts which otherwise mount the original hotend, so there are no further changes to the extruder necesssary to use the E3D v5 in this printer.
Thanks to jangermann, who helped in testing the adapter.

There are two versions of this adapter, a single part and a split version to be glued together. Just chose which version will be easier to print for you ... The fan mount is designed for the 30x30 fan that comes with the E3D v5, i.e. four 2.5 mm holes with 24 mm distance. It is recommended to replace the M3x25 bolts used for the original K8200 hotend with M3x30 bolts to fix the adapter. The washers should end up pressing both against the brackets and, on the edge, also against the second disk from below (see photo).
NB: the long M3 nuts are 5 mm wide across the flats, to there are exactly those 25 mm distance inbetween them needed to fit the E3D barrel, if they are rotated correctly. Please note that some E3D v5 barrels may have a top section with a height below 4 mm, while the cavity in the K8200 extruder base is approx. 4.0 - 4.1 mm deep. If this is the case for your E3D, you may have to insert a spacer, e.g. a washer, into the cavity in order to properly fix the hotend. The v6 mount includes a suitable stl file.

comments.text: Should this be printed in PLA or ABS?
comments.author: Reconnnn

comments.text: I've tried both without seeing any problems. ABS is surely preferred for use near the hotend, but as long as you install the fan and make sure it's on when the hotend is heated, the mount should be kept cool enough to also work in PLA. This is for room temperature of course, inside a heated environment PLA will probably soften too much.
comments.author: Reconnnn

comments.text: Alright great. How did you connect the fan on the controller board?
comments.author: kuraasu

comments.text: That's indeed a problem with the original K8200 / 3drag controller. You probably don't want to use the fan output, since you'll loose the adjustable cooling that way. However, you can set that output in the firmware to be associated with the hotend temperature, so it'll be on for say T > 50 °C. Second option is to connect the fan directly to the power supply screw terminal. This will, just like the first way, drive the fan at 15 V, which may be questionable for long term use. A resistor or voltage regulator (e.g. some 7812 variant) integrated in the cable could solve this. Third option is to use an auxiliary 12 V power supply.

description.text:
Work in progress.

This is a tower used to test different settings (e.g. temp, speed, layerheight) in one print. Must use a slicer capable of multiple sets of settings in one print (like Simplify3D), manually edit gcode files, or change settings on the printer manually during the print for desired test.

The tower has 5 sections each 10mm high.

Version 2 of the tower features:
-Small bridging test (cutouts 10mm & 5mm long)
-45 degree overhang test
-Letter test (1mm)

Version 3 of the tower adds the following features:
-Small tower test
-Stringing test (between main tower and small tower)

For all your cheese token generating needs. I made these for use as cheese tokens in Mice and Mystics. OpenSCAD provided to customize your cheese!

author: elJosho

description.text:
This low profile spacer was designed to mount a Hot Bed MOSFET PCB to a flat surface, allowing some clearance for the leads. This suits a MOSFET with 60x50mm PCB and mounting holes on 52x42mm centres. The holes at each corner are 3mm and include a countersink. There are two flat areas allow mounting with either screws or double-sided tape.

My board is this one (https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B06W5RJ9LY) based on the HA210N06 MOSFET. This board is widely available under lots of different brand names and the same thing ranges in price from about $10 to $40, so be sure to shop around.

author: Mthomp9838

description.text: This is a 3D fractal made for a math project with the 123D Design Software. The base is a cube from which each face is divided in order to obtain a tiling pattern of 5 diamonds with the same area. On each face, the middle diamond is kept and the 4 others around the middle one are extruded in the 3D modeling software. The pattern is repeated in the middle diamond. For this project, the pattern was repeated 3 times. However, I encountered a problem which i was not able to fix. If you look at the bottom face of the cube, two of the second level pattern diamonds did not want to be extruded properly. The rest of the cube is finished.

comments.text: This is mathematically beautiful - very clever.  Do you have any ideas on how to make it printable?

comments.text: Well I don't have much experience with 3D printing, but I included a .stl file with this post which should be compatible with 3d printers. title: Anycubic Kossel and Kossel Plus Stock Firmware

description.text:
• For stock trigorrila mainboard only.

  • The calibration steps below are are based on the method of constantly re-uploading firmware with small changes.

  • After making an adjustment in firmware, you must tell the machine to load these new settings, otherwise it will continue to use old settings stored in eeprom.
    To apply new settings after firmware upload, send m502 command, or select "Restore failsafe" from the LCD menu.

Latest stock marlin version RC8 firmwares pre-configured for Anycubic Kossel and Kossel Plus from google drive folder listed in the user manual:
https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B8VIB533cgdMSVMxNm43aG1OQ0U

Files are from folder 28/02/2017: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B8VIB533cgdMa1czMW5hNWlXYW8

  • Edit: Anycubic have been changing the contents of the google drive so only one firmware appears in there now for some reason..

Anycubic Youtube channel with updated build videos:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCTEanMUzF8pyGFqfbr65z2A/playlists

Install driver: youtu.be/kqMFelzXNc8
Install Arduino IDE: youtu.be/1TrOo_Cqh0Q
Upload firmware: youtu.be/DWFlqp8IDX4

Link to a pre-calibration and calibration tips video (from 2min49s): https://youtu.be/HSlgUx-LEhQ?t=2m49s
Link to a step by step video on calibrating marlin delta: https://youtu.be/QuEhQU8vGZk

A few more advanced bits on delta calibration: https://ladvien.github.io/robots/kossel-mini-calibration/

Cura slicer: https://ultimaker.com/en/products/cura-software
Cura quick start guide: https://ultimaker.com/en/resources/34185-quick-start-guides

Getting better prints: http://support.3dverkstan.se/article/30-getting-better-prints

Visually troubleshooting your prints (good info even if not using cura, ultimaker or simplify3d):
http://support.3dverkstan.se/article/23-a-visual-ultimaker-troubleshooting-guide
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

Advanced calibration for sizing and angle errors:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1274733
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745523

Attached 100x100x1mm test .stl file

Happy printing!!!

8thJul2017 Update: Anycubic have changed configuration.h files for both regular and plus, hopefully to provide starting settings closer to where they should end up.. I have added them here for convenience, ignore if already calibrated.

comments.author: thefatboy

comments.text: Set: #define E0_AUTO_FAN_PIN 44 in Configuration_adv.h. With the default configuration it will rn when the E0 temp will be above 50deg C. Probably you will get another error (cannot have E0_AUTO_FAN_PIN equals to FAN_PIN) thus you will have to #define FAN_PIN 9, under the hypothesis that you have connected the Extruder Fan on FAN2 and the blower fan on FAN0 as stated in the manual.

title: "French Horn" Filament Cooler for heavy bridging

description.text:
This is a filament cooler that I've designed for my Geeetech I3 B Pro printer. With slight adaptations might fit to other printers. Feel free to remix it.

It is made from 3 parts:

  • The cooler support that attaches the cooler to the extruder
  • The pipe adapter
  • The nozzle pipe

You can use the the nozzle pipe provided in the model but I recommend to make it from aluminium, see instructions bellow.

You will need:

  • Cooler Blower Turbo Fan DC 12V Fan with 50x50x15mm (see pics)
  • 3x M3 bolts ~5mm length
  • 1x M3 bolt 25mm
  • 1x M3 Nut

Here you can see the cooler in action, printing a simple [bridge test]:
https://youtu.be/JrjaLDI71sg

UPDATE 1 - This cooler was mainly designed for printing bridges. For normal objects disable the cooling or move the aluminium pipe a little bit away from the nozzle. You can also try to let the cooling enabled but remove the pipe completely letting the air to flow from distance

Printer:

Geeetech I3 Pro B

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

I recommend cutting 4-5 cm from an 8mm x 1mm Aluminium pipe. One side leave it as it is, the other squash it a little and file it as depicted here Bring the pipe as close as possible to the nozzle. Be sure that the air blows where the filament exits If the pipe slides out fix it with an extra bolt I rotated the nozzle head to get access to the nozzle from the front side

print_settings.Notes:: The electronics case lid slides into place and is held in place by slotted rails. The rails need to be printed with a relatively fine resolution (I used 0.2mm, 0.3mm would probably be fine too). You may need to tidy these up a bit with a craft knife after printing to make the lid slide on.

description.text:
A simple case for RAMPS and Arduino, plus the Reprap discount smart controller display. Also added a couple of very simple holding brackets for an ATX power supply, so you can mount it out of the way under a table. I thought it might be a good project to design some parts to keep my 3D printer tidy! Designed in FreeCAD, I'm happy to share the FCStd files if you wish, send me a message.

Both cases clip onto the base of the printer using the 'Chassis_clip' part. You'll need some M3 machine screws to attach them to the cases, and some M3 screws and plastic washers to attach the Reprap controller to the case. There is space for an on/off switch at the side of the display case, I use this to disable my ATX power supply so I can cut the power if something is going wrong! It normally stays on all the time and I switch the printer on/off with software.

The display case is best printed with the 'top' face down on the print surface (I think). You'll need to print supports for the SD card slot and switch space. I used the default coarse support in KISSlicer and that worked well.

The electronics case has space for two 40mm fans. I connected these to a fan extender and run them only when the motors are on, but you could run them all the time if you don't want to bother with a fan extender. I printed this with supports for the fan holes, again the default coarse supports on KISSlicer worked well.

The ATX power supply brackets were designed for my CX430 power supply (pictured) but should work with others too. You'll need some tapered head screws to fasten the brackets to the underside of your table/bench.

Before you print this, please bear in mind that there are a lot of slightly different versions of RAMPS and Reprap Discount Smart Controllers out there - I strongly recommend you check the STLs will fit the parts you have before printing, as some of the parts take a while to print!

Hope someone else finds this useful - thanks for checking out my design!

Printer:

Openbeam Kossel XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 (important for the electronics case lid)

Infill:

Not important - I used 25%

Notes:

The electronics case lid slides into place and is held in place by slotted rails. The rails need to be printed with a relatively fine resolution (I used 0.2mm, 0.3mm would probably be fine too). You may need to tidy these up a bit with a craft knife after printing to make the lid slide on.

This is a block that should fit two Seimitsu PS-14 24mm screw-in buttons. It has wire routes on all four sides. I designed this to use with a CST Trackball with two external button jacks.

I have not attempted to print this design.
Designed in Catia, printed to my son for Comicon. Naples, Italy, 2017 edition.

description.text:
This panel mount allows Plexiglas panels or other panel materials to be mounted within 2020 aluminum extrusion frames. I used them to add a panel to the bottom of my HyperCube printer. The mounts provide the advantage of placing the mounting hole well away from the edge and putting gentle pressure on a wider area rather than a concentrated screw hole so that cracking is less likely . Using these mounts also makes the panel easy to remove without internal access.

To use these panel mounts, drill a 6 mm hole in the panel 12 mm from the edge. Attach the mount with the bushing and a 3 mm x 8 mm screw and washer. Use a 5 mm screw and extrusion T-Nut to mount the other end to your 2020 extrusion. The bushing hole is self tapping.

The mount is designed for 3 mm thick panels but can be used with thicker panels. For thinner panels, you may need to shorten the bushing.

This is the HyperCube Printer I am using these panel mounts on.

If you'd like to purchase a kit from me please go to:
http://www.carbonfrog.com/Products/MD305V2.html This is a MOSFET driver board to enable the control of a cooling fan from a Sanguinololu board using Sprinter firmware. I have included a protection diode and suppressing capacitor which is overkill if you are using a PC/GPU brushless DC motor fan but I wanted to make this drive general purpose for use in other expansion projects and experiments.
I also considered having this made by a PCB maker using SMD's but I would probably need to order a couple of hundred units to make it worth while as its such a small circuit. I think this would be a useful prototyping gadget for Arduino projects as well as 3d printer upgrades as it could be made really small using SMD's, small enough even to tuck inside a cable sleeve. I'd love to have a bunch of these in my tool box as it would save a lot of time faffing with breadboards when you just want to try something quickly. So if anyone else is interested in buying one or two let me know and if enough people show willing I'll advance the project. UPDATE
I have refined the design of this driver and had some boards made up. It's an SMD design and I've made it as small as possible while still allowing various connector/wiring possibilities. I'm currently making it available as a kit as not everyone has the necessary materials to hand and it can be a pain trying to source one of a particular 0603 resistor.
If you'd like to purchase a kit from me please go to:
http://www.carbonfrog.com/Products/MD305V2.html If you'd like just a board or a kit with slightly different parts let me know and if enough people ask for a particular packing list I'll make it available. The kit comes with a brief instruction card but I'm compiling more comprehensive instructions. As soon as they are done I'll upload them and some new photos. Meanwhile please check out my listing above.
Buy the way before anyone asks the supplied transistor is an IRLML0030TRPBF.

You will need 1x RF540A MOSFET
1x 1N4001 Diode
1x 1K Ohm Resistor
1x 6.7K Ohm Resistor
1x 0.1uF Capacitor
1x 7 rows x 5 tracks Stripboard
1x 2way header male Connector
1x 3way header male Connector Solder, Wire, Connectors etc. Make up the PCB.
Coat circuit board both sides with hot melt but leave the MOSFETs heatsink and the connection pins exposed.
Wire up.
Open up you arduino IDE, go to the pins file and scroll down to the motherboard 62 section.
Locate the FAN_PIN value, it should be -1, change it to 4.
Save, compile and upload the firmware to your Sanguinololu. You can test your fan by sending the following commands: M106 This will turn the fan on
M107 This will turn the fan off
M106 S127 This will turn the fan on at half speed.
(You can set any speed from 0 to 255) There will be a cooling fan option somewhere in your slicing options. Use it and enjoy finer more accurate prints.

comments.text:
The exact type of snubber circuit you use
depends on many things. The circuit on the Wikipedia page is a flyback circuit
so the current will reverse and the diode is configured to stop it. In my
circuit I wanted to absorb any back emf if a regular dc motor was used. My
circuit is only intended for current flowing in one direction, so any back emf
is directed back up to the high rail and impeded by the capacitor (reactance).
If a large solenoid was to be used with my circuit then additional emf
protection would be recommended. I hope this clearers things up for you however
this is a fairly big subject and emf protection depends on the situation. My
circuit is intended for connecting small motors etc. to Arduinos and the diode
and capacitor just add a little extra protection.

comments.text: I know it can be tricky to place SMD components by hand ( I've done quite a few myself) but with the right tools and the right technique it gets easier. Here's a couple of tips. First ( very important ) with solder paste less is more, providing you have paste touching the pad and pin any more will just cause you problems it always astonishes me just how little you need to make a really reliable joint. Secondly perfect a way of positioning the components. The way I do it is to first put the component in the correct orientation on a blank space on the board near to its location. Then get a sharp pair of tweezers. now rest your hand on the bench holding the tweezers so its comfortable and easy to open and close the tweezers precisely and pivot your hand so the tweezers move up and down ( in Z ). Now with your other hand nudge the board around with your fingers ( in X & Y). The mistake is to try and do all 3 with your tweezering hand. If you do your hand will drag on the bench making precision movements in X & Y very difficulty and you will have trouble controlling the pressure on the tweezers grip. You will also find you can get really good precision placement by nudging and rolling your fingertip against the edges of the board. Hope this helps. In the near future I may do a tutorial on this ( maybe a video)  if anyone is interested.

comments.text: A couple notes regarding the components:
comments.author: imitation

comments.text:
Thanks for your comments, I admit this is not the perfect driver I would like or would have made at a PCB makers, but I threw this together with components I had laying around on my bench (it took me longer to write it up). However I would always use resistors in this configuration as the more you limit current being draw through the micro the better. I
Ã¢Â€Â™m new to the Atmel chips (IÃ¢Â€Â™m a PIC man) and have yet to find my way around their data sheets, but I usually find that although you can draw up to 40mA through an I/O pin there is a lower total load you can put on all the pins. Also I always use a pull down as on similar circuits IÃ¢Â€Â™ve experie
nced MOSFETÃ¢Â€Â™s turning on momentarily as the micro goes through its start up procedures (this class of MOSFET has a habit of turning on at the drop of a hat.) In robotics things just turning on when you donÃ¢Â€Â™t intend, can be really bad. There are more elaborate hold off circuits you can use but th
is is a simple but effective way that works well in most cases. The capacitor was a bad choice but I have my eye on some SMD ceramics that are great for suppressing inductive loads, yes, I know thatÃ¢Â€Â™s not a problem here but I want a general purpose driver that could handle a largish DC motor.

"Also I always use a pull down as on similar circuits I
Ã¢Â€Â™ve experienced MOSFETÃ¢Â€Â™s turning on momentarily as the micro goes through its start up procedures"
Good point. You might want to consider adjusting the voltage divider that the 1k and 6k8 resistors form, though - in this configuration, only ~4.35V reach the gate (probably a little less), limitin
g the FET's driving capabilities to around 5A. The attached image is taken from ST's irl540 datasheet (two graphs).
A weaker logic-level FET (i have some irliz34n kicking around) allows for larger currents at these low gate voltages (one graph, taken from IR's irliz34n datasheet). At the same voltag
e, the irliz34n will already drive around 20A.
comments.author: Danjhamer

comments.text: The 1k resistor is required for driving a FET like like a IRF540, because the gate capacitance will cause excess current when it is turned on without current limitiing, and that will cause noise and flyback problems.
so, is the diode needed?

That depends on what kind of load you're running. For a low-current load (PC fan) or one that is mostly resistive (like a PCB heater, hotend etc...), no. For partially- or fully-inductive loads, like larger DC motors (i'd say anything larger than a 380) or anything that involves coils, yes, definitely, or else your transistor might release its magic smoke, depending on what voltage it is rated for.
comments.author: hariseldon

comments.text: You could cut the size of the unit almost in half by bending the FET down on the front or back of the board, you just need to cut the leads longer and (if you put it on the back) make sure that the heatsink tab is insulated from the soldered leads.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text:
That
Ã¢Â€Â™s a great idea that would be good in some situations, however I like to have the heatsinks well exposed for cooling and bolting to some additional heatsinking. I was also going for long and thin rather that overall compactness. If I get something manufactured itÃ¢Â€Â™ll be inline so it can go inside
cable sleeving.

author: maxik

description.text: I found myself bored one day and decided to make a custom watch stand for my Hawker hurricane inspired watch. It is designed after that specific watch but should work for other 45mm diameter watches no guarantees though.

title: Miata NC Bose aux jack replacement

description.text:
I replaced the factory Bose radio in my 2011 Miata SE and wanted to retain the aux jack. The factory jack has a proprietary connector on the back so I created this which has a 7mm hole where a standard 3.5mm panel mount stereo jack can fit. I made it in two parts for easy printing. There are registration nubs to help align it when gluing. I printed in ABS, smoothed the front with acetone and glued it together with CA glue.

Here's a link to the Fusion 360 file if you want to make your own version: http://a360.co/2zc0Ovd

comments.text: could you create a version with 1-2 usb jack sockets?

title: Iphone 6/7 Plus (with case) Stand (w/ rigidity fins)

description.text:
This is a remix of a remix of an iphone 6/7 Plus stand. The previous one was a bit flimsy if printed in cheap PLA and the back would break off with any pressure. This remix adds fins for rigidity that makes the back stronger regardless of what cheap filament you use.

Remix was made in tinker-cad. (its not too powerful but its so easy to use)

No supports, 15% infill for attractive top surfaces though 10% is plenty strong.

author: diamonddrake

description.text:
Battery cover for the vintage Coleco Tabletop arcade games. I modeled this off of a Frogger game that I had but I believe they all used the same one as the cases were all the same design just molded in different colors.

Settings:

This was printed with supports at 2 mm spacing. These are required for the two guide tabs on the back and the clip tongue at the front.

Finishing:

The original had molded feet that were on the bottom but because I was using the bottom as my ground plane I had to make a second model for the feet. You will need to print two of them and I have included two guide holes in the bottom that you can line up with the pin on top of the feet then glue. Also I believe that the originals had a small piece of sponge glued to the inside face between the two raised portions to apply pressure to the batteries to keep them from sagging. Any small cell sponge or foam should work fine.

Prusa I3 MK2

description.text:
A LED grow lamp for indoor gardening, supplements natural light after the sunset, before the dawn and on cloudy days. Fits Ikea's LACK coffee table
http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/40104294/#/10104295

The lamp allows natural light through, can be adjusted to any height and is easily removed when watering the plants.

Materials used:
16 feet grow light LED strip and power supply
6 3'x0.5''x0.125'' aluminum flats
https://www.lowes.ca/metal-products/the-hillman-group-113-aluminum-flat-bar_g1199940.html
1 4'x0.5"x0.5" aluminum trim channel
https://www.lowes.ca/metal-products/the-hillman-group-113-aluminum-trim-channel_g1185899.html
4 5/16 3' threaded rods and 16 nuts
2 M2 12mm bolts and nuts
12 4-40 x 1/2' bolts and nuts
4 6-32 x 1' bolts and nuts
20 awg wire
heat shrink tubing
foam tape to insure snag fit of the parts on the table legs
acrylic paint for 3d printed parts - optional

The total cost of materials was around $75.

Tools needed:
drill, handsaw for drilling and cutting aluminum
soldering iron and solder

I designed and printed this for my cousin. He's currently really into the game the Escapists. I just looked at some of the imagery from the game and used a pixel art drawing tool with OpenSCAD.

I chose to print it two toned. I changed the filament colour when it started printing the raised detail. I used Prusa's colourprint to generate the change filament gcode.

The set includes 2 5.6cm tall toys: a prison guard and a prisioner. And a hinged prison cell door. For printing simplicity, I separately printed feet to keep the door upright.

An aluminium Ice Sphere Maker. Take a large Ice Cube, place it in the crushinator sphere chamber, place the top on, and let the thermogravatational magic happen. You'll be left with a perfect Ice Sphere

You could print this fairly easily as a sphere shaped mold for clay or what have you, however to make one that will properly melt ice into a sphere, you'll need the fast talking, sweet heat moving, dense ductile material known as Aluminium, and you'll also need a CNC mill or lathe (I did mine on a mill) Using a drill, a square endmill for the rough cut and a ball end mill for the finish pass, I made mine in about 2 hours on a little home hobby CNC mill. I've been churning out Ice balls ever since. Here's a youtube video of the CNC ing
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1ryR4s1g3z8

comments.text: Cool part. These are common in high end bars in Japan. Other shapes can be made rather than spheres... someone mentioned it would be cool to do a diamond shaped one before... perhaps using this shape http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9822http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... or a more cleaned up one like this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19137http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: M_G

comments.text: It's definitely possible to do other shapes, the reason I did a sphere is the surface area to volume ratio (lowest of any shape), which basically means the ice will take longer to melt, and your whiskey won't get watered down as quickly (this is why they have them at high end bars).
comments.author: M_G

comments.text: You could do a diamond with rounded edges. Place the diamond "sideways" so that the longest dimensions of the diamond are side to side rather than up and down. Make it so that an 1/8" ball end mill cuts the final grooves. It would take a very long time, but that's what CNC mills are for!

comments.text: :) there is also a couple of tricks to make the ice transparent. First, you need distilled water. Than you need to additionally cook it right before the freezing. This will get rid of dissolved gases. And, try to freeze a waterbath in a big vessel, that is insulated from below. So it only cools from the top. And, do not freeze completely. As long as there is some water left, it will contain a lot of the leftover inpurities.

title: Anet A6 Y axis stabilising spacer

description.text:
This is a spacer for the Y axis, between the threaded rods and the frame (the U shaped gap in the middle section, not the hole in the back). It stabilizes the Y axis, preventing the slight slack parallel to the X axis.
To install it, you will need to remove the entire Y axis assembly. Remove the nuts and washers to place the spacer in the correct position on the threaded rod and then replace them. Holding just the threaded rod assembly, push the spacer into the gap in the frame, this may take quite a large amount of force so be sure not to bend the rod or break the frame. This will cause the spacer to be squashed into the frame making it very rigid. Repeat with the other threaded rod and re-assemble the Y-axis assembly.

description.text:
QX13 BUTT-CAN ADAPTOR LEAVES

Please see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2220337 for the “STEM” to this project!

This file is provided for personal education and study ONLY! (The stem portion is commons, share-alike, attribution! But this file is for study only!) The leaves are a replica of the cap to the Gogo Squeez applesauce pouch. It could arguably be considered a trademark. But this file can be used personally to experiment with:

  • Large Models.
  • Adhesive Techniques. (I used J.B. Plastic Weld on PLA)
  • Adapting connecting components to your own unique design.

I created the Bodies in FUSION 360. The pieces are mirrored, so only one piece-file is required. You can Boolean-add them in a cad program and then create your own design using similar techniques.

THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS! I am already redesigning this project in multiple pieces that would not require glue!

STEP files are included for the single, and the double versions so that you can modify them in a cad program. Have fun!

This was sliced and coded using ReplicatorG employing 2 shells (3 total) using PLA.

  • FlashForge Creator Pro (Similar to Makerbot Replicator 2)
  • Heated Bed 45 Celsius
  • Blue Painters Tape on bed, no further treatment
  • Print Temperature 220 degrees Celsius
  • Supports, NO rafts.
  • Feedrate 40 mm/s
  • Travel Feedrate 55
    (If anybody has more optimum feedrates, please share!)

REQUEST: Please help me improve my sharing! STEP files have proven reliable for me to transport file between different CAD platforms. If STEPs are a problem for you, please let me know what other common and relatively generic Cad format works better for you.

QX13 BUTT-CAN ADAPTOR STEM

Please see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2220336 for an example of a TOP to this project! Also, a close approximation of the can is provided in that file for educational modeling purposes.

This is a stem/post for an “Eagle Butt-Can” Model 1200 and 1206. The old one was damaged. The parts list:

  • QX13 Can Cover: (Adaptor Plate!) Insert two 6mm Hex Head bolts about 40mm long from the bottom, affix to Eagle Butt-Can (Model 1200 and 1206 work, for sure!) using two 5mm self-taping sheet-metal screws, or similar. Be sure to print 2 walls (3 total)!
  • QX13 Mound: After the remaining pieces are assembled and ready to mount, this is placed on top of the 6mm bolts protruding from mounted Can-Cover, and affixed with 6mm Wing Nuts. It has the first section of the stem built right in! Be sure to print 2 walls (3 total)!
  • QX13 Stem a: Print TWO of these for the next two sections. I didn’t require any glue, they fit so good! Place on a flat surface, line up your pieces, and thrust in-place squarely! Be sure to print 2 walls (3 total)!
  • QX13 Stem a Top: Print One of these. It’s the final stem piece, the top of which is slightly modified for the geometry of the Topper. Be sure to print 2 walls (3 total)!

I created the Bodies in FUSION 360.

STEP files are included so that you can modify them in a cad program. Have fun!

This was sliced and coded using ReplicatorG employing 2 shells (3 total) using PLA.

  • FlashForge Creator Pro (Similar to Makerbot Replicator 2)
  • Heated Bed 45 Celsius
  • Blue Painters Tape on bed, no further treatment
  • Print Temperature 220 degrees Celsius
  • Supports for QX13 MOUND, others; No Supports, NO rafts.
  • Feedrate 40 mm/s
  • Travel Feedrate 55
    (If anybody has more optimum feedrates, please share!)

REQUEST: Please help me improve my sharing! STEP files have proven reliable for me to transport file between different CAD platforms. If STEPs are a problem for you, please let me know what other common and relatively generic Cad format works better for you.

description.text:
A magnetic stirrer is a desktop helper to mix any liquid solution. This is probably one of the simplest way to make one, as it involves a reduced number of parts that can be reclaimed ones. With brand new parts, this build will cost you under 5€.

BOM :
1x enclosure (printed or DIY)
1x Power Switch 6mm 3P
1x USB-A inlet
1x 60mm fan (12v)
1x 5mm led (optional)
1x 180 ohms resistor (optional)
5x 6x8mm neodymium magnets : 2x for the rotor, 3x for the stir bar (flea)
Or 2x 6x8 neodymium magnets for the rotor + 1x stir bar (20>30mm or +-1")

Build instructions : https://youtu.be/6bDGU4-4F88

Printer:

prusa i3, CoreXY, Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layers

Infill:

85% (solid infill)
Pack the stir bar into packing tape to avoid corrosion.

The simpler the better

Most of the DIY magnetic stirrers uses a 12v fan powered by a 12v PSU. But they uses a potentiometer to step down the voltage. To be able to vary the voltage can be usefull, but usualy you will power the fan with 3 to 6v. 3v is for a very gentle stirring and 6v is very fast. So what if you power the stirrer with +5v USB power ? Well it's the good idea : except if you do fine chemicals, it works with 80% of the maker's needs and you probably already have USB ports available anywhere. So all you really need is a power switch and a fan.

title: Metric drill bit holder and magnet

description.text:
I bought this 13 piece titanium metric drill bits from Amazon, https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00M4U3Y34/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 but the case that it came with was not that great. The hinge was cracked so it did not stay closed and the labels for each drill bit size is very hard to read. Instead of trying to fix the hinge and have it probably not last I decided to use joaquinfq's "Customizable Drill Holder". This allowed me to create a case that holds the drill bits nicely.

I imported the file that the customizer outputted and I added numbers to identify each drill bit size.

I also create a little grabber that holds a magnet. Some of the drill bits are small which makes them hard to get out. The grabber holds a square neodymium magnet sized 5mm x 5mmx 3mm. I bought mine from Wish (https://www.wish.com/c/54acfc554274a22214c95a6e).

I then took a metallic silver sharpie and colored the top of each number to make them stand out a bit more.

The cover at first was tight but is a bit loose now so I just use a rubber band to keep it all secure. I don't know if I would trust the lid even if it was tight.

Filament is Hatchbox's orange:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00J0EE1D4/ref=od_aui_detailpages00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

edit: I have included a wood drill bit holder for pimar3D. He wanted some changes for the box to hold 3mm x 62mm, 4mm x 75mm, 5mm x 86mm, 6mm x 92mm, 7mm x 110mm, 8mm x 117mm, 10mm x 134mm, 12mm x 152mm, 14mm x 170mm.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The grabber I printed with a resolution of 0.1 because it is a small item. That was also printed without a raft.

I turned the grabber so the open end is facing my cooling fan to help stop the plastic from dropping.

Place each drill bit in the appropriate spot.

Insert a square neodymium magnet (5mm x 5mm x 3mm) from Wish (https://www.wish.com/c/54acfc554274a22214c95a6e) and use a bit of super glue to hold it in.

I used joaquinfq's Customizable Drill Holder file to create the box and the lid. I then imported the box into TinkerCAD to add the numbers for the drill bit size.

I created the grabber in Fusion 360.
